revision.text:
[[Image:TerraMax 2 hr.jpg|thumb|An Oshkosh 4x4 MTVR fitted with TerraMax autonomous technology; this vehicle had previously participated in 2007 DARPA Grand Challenge]] '''TerraMax''' is the trademark for [[Autonomous car|autonomous]]/[[unmanned ground vehicle]] technology developed by [[Oshkosh Corporation|Oshkosh Defense]].<ref name="TerraMax">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/technology-1/unmanned-ground-vehicle/#overview|title=WHEN YOU’D RATHER NOT SEND ANYONE|publisher=Oshkosh Defense|accessdate=2016-02-24}}</ref> Primary military uses for the technology are seen as [[reconnaissance]] missions and freight transport in high-risk areas so freeing soldiers from possible attacks, [[ambushes]] or the threat of mines and [[Improvised explosive device|IEDs]].<ref name="TerraMax"/> The technology could also be used in civilian settings, such as autonomous [[Snow removal|snow clearing]] at airports.<ref name="Detecting roadside bombs">{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/06/oshkosh-autonomous-minesweeping/|title=TerraMax|publisher=wired.com|accessdate=2016-02-24}}</ref>
The original TerraMax vehicle was based on Oshkosh’s 6x6 [[Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement]] (MTVR) and this was entered in the 2004 and 2005 [[DARPA]] Grand Challenges.<ref name="DARPA GRAND CHALLENGE">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/events/darpa-grand-challenge/|title=Team Oshkosh TerraMax Media Fact Sheet|publisher=Oshkosh Defense|accessdate=2016-02-24}}</ref> A 4x4 variant was subsequently developed for, and entered in, the 2007 [[DARPA]] Urban Challenge.<ref name="DARPA URBAN CHALLENGE">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/events/darpa-urban-challenge/|title=DARPA Urban Challenge|publisher=Oshkosh Defense|accessdate=2016-02-24}}</ref> Since then, Oshkosh has continued developing the technology and in addition to four MTVRs has fitted the technology to its [[Palletized Load System]] (PLS),<ref name="Oshkosh Truck Unveils Next Generation of Unmanned Defense Logistics Vehicle">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/news/oshkosh-truck-unveils-next-generation-of-unmanned-defense-logistics-vehicle/|title=Oshkosh Truck Unveils Next Generation of Unmanned Defense Logistics Vehicle|publisher=Oshkosh|accessdate=2016-02-24}}</ref> [[Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles]] (FMTV).<ref name="TerraMax UGV"/> and [[Oshkosh M-ATV|MRAP All Terrain Vehicle (M-ATV)]].<ref name="Detecting roadside bombs"/>
==Development and history== Oshkosh actively commenced development of the TerraMax in mid-2003. In the [[DARPA Grand Challenge (2004)|2004 DARPA Grand Challenge]] (March 13–14, 2004) Team TerraMax was one of only seven teams to successfully navigate the qualifying course, going on to manage 1.2 miles on the race course before being ‘confronted’ by an impassable bush. The 2004 Team TerraMax consisted of Oshkosh Truck (now Oshkosh Defense), [[University of Parma]]'s Artificial Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory ([[VisLab]]), [[Teledyne Technologies|Teledyne Scientific Company]], [[Auburn University]], IBEO and [[Caterpillar Inc.|Caterpillar]]. At the time, Don Verhoff, [[Oshkosh Corporation|Oshkosh's]] executive vice president of technology explained that: "although design development may continue for years, the idea of a driverless convoy of defense vehicles to deliver supplies to the front line, never jeopardizing the welfare of a single driver, is closer than one might imagine."
In October 2005 a second-generation TerraMax was one of five vehicles to complete the [[DARPA Grand Challenge (2005)|2005 DARPA Grand Challenge]] 132-mile desert course. Unofficial run time was 12 hours and 51 minutes, this outside of the 10-hour limit to qualify for the $2 million prize money. The 2005 Team TerraMax consisted of Oshkosh Truck, [[Rockwell Collins]], University of Parma's Artificial Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory ([[VisLab]]) and several financial sponsors.
Continuing development of TerraMax technologies, in January 2006 Oshkosh unveiled an unmanned version of its [[Palletized Load System]] (PLS) truck at the U.S. Army Tactical Wheeled Vehicle Component Technology Demonstrations in Yuma, Arizona. East.<ref name="Driverless TerraMax completes DARPA Grand Challenge">{{cite web |url=https://janes.ihs.com/Janes/Display/1104931|title=Driverless TerraMax completes DARPA Grand Challenge|publisher=International Defence Digest (IHS Jane's)|date=2005-10-18|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
In 2007 Team TerraMax competed in the [[DARPA Grand Challenge (2007)|DARPA Urban Challenge]] with a 4x4 MTVR. In June 2010, Oshkosh Defense was awarded the U.S. Marine Corps Cargo UGV (CUGV) initiative contract. The contract was awarded by [[United States Marine Corps|US Marine Corps]] Warfighting Laboratory ([[United States Marine Corps Warfighting Laboratory|MCWL]]) and the Joint Ground Robotics Enterprise Robotics Technology Consortium. The first evaluation for the cargo UGV was completed in May 2011 at [[Fort Pickett]].<ref name="TerraMax UGV">{{cite web |url=https://janes.ihs.com/Janes/Display/1495426|title=TerraMax Large wheeled logistics UGV|publisher=IHS Jane's|date=2015-11-19|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
In October 2010 at the [[Association of the United States Army]] (AUSA) Annual Meeting and Exposition at the [[Washington Convention Center]], Oshkosh displayed an [[Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles|FMTV]] Load Handling System (LHS) variant fitted with TerraMax technology.
In May 2014 Oshkosh announced that to demonstrate capabilities for [[Route clearance (IEDs)|route-clearance]] missions it had integrated its TerraMax [[unmanned ground vehicle]] (UGV) technology onto an Oshkosh [[Oshkosh M-ATV|MRAP All-Terrain Vehicle (M-ATV)]]. The vehicle was demonstrated in June 2014 at the [[Eurosatory]] defence exhibition in [[Paris]] where it was equipped with a [[mine roller]] and autonomously navigated a course that simulated military [[Route clearance (IEDs)|route clearance]] missions.<ref name="TerraMax route clearence product sheet">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/components/terramax/#lit|title=TerraMax route clearance product sheet|publisher=Oshkosh Defense|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
The company was awarded a contract to evaluate the CUGV as a route clearing UGV, an effort that saw three vehicles working together. The trials took place at [[Fort A.P. Hill]], [[Virginia]], in April 2015.<ref name="TerraMax UGV"/> Also in 2015, the US Army worked on requirements documentation for the introduction of leader-follower technology for the Oshkosh 10×10 PLS logistics and support vehicles, which would be used initially as a driver safety mechanism for functions such as braking. In 2016, TerraMax-equipped vehicles took part in the Autonomous Ground Resupply Programme. Under the programme, the vehicles were expected to demonstrate the carrying of cargo from the point of embarkation to a forward-operating base (FOB) and then to a patrol base.
===Other autonomous projects=== [[File:TerraMax.jpg|thumb|right|Oshkosh received USD49 million to integrate autonomous technology onto PLS vehicles as part of the ExLF programme.]] Oshkosh is also involved in a number of other autonomous vehicle projects in conjunction with partners that include [[United States Army Tank Automotive Research, Development and Engineering Center|TARDEC]], [[Lockheed Martin]], Robotic Research, and DCS.
In 2016, Oshkosh PLS vehicles took part in the Autonomous Ground Resupply Programme. Under the programme, the vehicles were expected to demonstrate the carrying of cargo from the point of embarkation to a forward-operating base (FOB) and then to a patrol base.
On 27 June 2018, as part of the Expedient Leader Follower (ExLF) programme, Oshkosh received USD49 million to integrate its autonomous technology onto [[Palletized load system|PLS]] vehicles. The TARDEC-led programme was awarded through an Other Transaction Authority (OTA) contract and is intended to facilitate the transition to an official Program of Record. The programme is expected to last until the end of its contract term in March 2021.
Ten vehicles will be integrated with autonomous technology and will undergo government qualification and safety testing in early 2019. In early 2019 there will be another integration on 60 vehicles which will then be sent for the operational technical demonstration (OTD), which will be in early 2020.
Oshkosh began integrating an initial 10 autonomy kits upon the award for the engineering test, verification, validation, and ATEC Safety Release, and will integrate another 60 kits for fiscal year 2019 for OTDs. The OTDs will occur in the second quarter of fiscal year 2020. The contract holds an option to procure up to 150 autonomy kits.<ref name="TerraMax August 2018">{{cite web |url=https://janes.ihs.com/Janes/Display/jugv0277-jlsu|title=TerraMax August 2018 update|publisher=IHS Jane'|date=2018-09-21|accessdate=2018-11-12}}</ref>
==Technology== TerraMax Unmanned Ground Vehicle (UGV) technology is [[modularity|modular]] and designed to be integrated into any tactical wheeled vehicle. The components of TerraMax are located so as not to impede the combat requirements of soldiers, while maintaining the utility of the vehicle. The technology is fully incorporated into the brakes, steering, engine and transmission. Fitted vehicles retain the ability to be driver-operated. Fitted vehicles can be operated fully autonomously in any position in a [[convoy]], or semi-autonomously to follow the path of the lead vehicle.<ref name="TerraMax overview product sheet">{{cite web |url=http://oshkoshdefense.com/components/terramax/#lit|title=TerraMax overview product sheet|publisher=Oshkosh Defense|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
The TerraMax UGV package consists of Oshkosh’s Command Zone electronics, a sensor suite and an advanced operator control unit (OCU).<ref name="TerraMax"/>
Command Zone is an integrated control and [[diagnosis|diagnostics]] system that is computer-controlled, electronics technology that operates and diagnoses all major vehicle networks. The backbone of the Command Zone system is advanced [[multiplexing]] technology.<ref name="TerraMax"/>
The multimodal [[sensor]] suite consists of a high definition [[LIDAR]]<ref name="Forward roll: the next generation of route clearance">{{cite web |url=https://janes.ihs.com/Janes/Display/1495426|title=LIDAR|publisher=IHS Jane's IDR|date=2013-11-04|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref> (light detection and ranging) system, a wide dynamic range camera, a short wave [[infrared]] camera, four situational awareness cameras, 12 short range [[radar]] systems (providing 360° close-view) and three long range radar systems. The military grade global navigation satellite system (GNSS) along with map registration software technology ensures the operation of the system without a satellite signal where a [[global positioning system]] (GPS) navigation system is blocked or denied.<ref name="TerraMax"/>
The vehicle mounted with TerraMax UGV technology is autonomously controlled by an operator control unit (OCU). It enables the operators to manipulate route information and look out or manage internal operations and status of autonomous systems over tactical data links. The tele-operated OCU shows the necessary information according to the priority and facilitates the fast input of commands to maintain the pace in convoy operations. The screen of OCU displays overhead imagery, automated routes and driving parameters. It gives feedback if it identifies an obstacle to continue, or changes track accordingly. The OCU allows a single operator to control one or more UGVs. The operator can control an UGV with infrequent monitoring of the unit.<ref name="TerraMax"/><ref name="Oshkosh TerraMax Unmanned Ground Vehicle Technology, United States of America">{{cite web |url=http://www.army-technology.com/projects/oshkosh-terramax-unmanned-ground-vehicle/|title=Oshkosh TerraMax Unmanned Ground Vehicle Technology, United States of America|publisher=army-technology.com|accessdate=2016-02-25}}{{Unreliable source?|reason=domain on WP:BLACKLIST|date=June 2016}}</ref>
From an earlier statement that it desired one third of its fleet to be autonomous by 2015, the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] now believes that the technology for autonomous vehicles may be ready for the field by 2025. At an AUVSI symposium in [[Arlington, Virginia]] in October 2015, Dr Paul Rogers, director of the army's [[United States Army Tank Automotive Research, Development and Engineering Center|Tank Automotive Research Development and Engineering Center]] (TARDEC), said "Autonomous convoy technology for the US army remains about 10 years away, depending on how the acquisition process moves, due to requirements, testing, and [[budget]]ing processes."<ref name="Autonomous convoy tech still years away from US Army fielding">{{cite web |url=https://janes.ihs.com/Janes/Display/1755521|title=Autonomous convoy tech still years away from US Army fielding|publisher=IHS Jane's|date=2015-10-29|accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
==Television== The TerraMax was featured in Series 19 of [[BBC]] Television series ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]''. It was featured against presenter [[James May]] in the [[Range Rover]] in an off-road challenge in the Nevada Automotive Test Center, Nevada, USA.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b01r2ckq/Top_Gear_Series_19_Episode_5/ TerraMax featured in Top Gear, from 22:38]</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery caption="" widths="240px" heights="200px"> File:DARPA-2005.jpg|MTVR 6x6 participating in the DARPA 2005 Grand Challenge File:Terramax-DARPAChallenge04.jpg|TerraMax at the [[DARPA Grand Challenge#2004 Grand Challenge|2004 DARPA Grand Challenge]] File:MTVR with TerraMax.jpg|MTVR with TerraMax File:TerraMax Op control unit.jpg|Operator Control Unit and Interface for TerraMax File:M-ATV with TerraMax.jpg|M-ATV (with mine roller attachment) with TerraMax File:M-ATV with TerraMax callouts desert.jpg|In convoy, an M-ATV with mine roller attachment) and two MTVRs with TerraMax. The third MTVR is manned
</gallery>
==See also== *Oshkosh [[Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement]] (MTVR) *[[Oshkosh M-ATV]] *[[Oshkosh Corporation]] *[[Palletized load system]] *[[Unmanned ground vehicle]] *[[Vehicular automation]] *[[Autonomous logistics]] *[[DARPA Grand Challenge]] *[[Top Gear (series 19)]] (TerraMax vs. Range Rover)

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:The Science Alliance.jpg|right|200px]]'''''The Science Alliance''''' was an educational television show which was produced and broadcast by [[TVOntario]] in 1981-82. The hosts were [[Rex Hagon]] and [[Judy Haladay]].
The typical episode would feature the hosts demonstrating various aspect of the subject of the episode. In addition, a largely unseen narrator named Bryant would interrupt at pertinent points with a vignette called "Bryant's Giants of Science" which would tell the story of a figure in the history of science and his contribution to scientific knowledge.
==Episode list==
11 episodes were produced. They were:
# "Magnets" # "Electricity" # "Matter" # "Energy" # "Machines" # "Heat" # "Air" # "Sound" # "Light" # "Water" # "Safety"
All episodes were 15 minutes in length.
==External links== * {{IMDb title|2734246|The Science Alliance}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Science Alliance, The}} [[Category:TVOntario shows]] [[Category:Television shows set in Hamilton, Ontario]] [[Category:Canadian children's television series]] [[Category:Science education television series]] [[Category:1981 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:1982 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:1980s Canadian television series]]
{{Canada-tv-prog-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[Image:Thomas Cook (machinist).jpg|thumb|upright|right|Thomas Cooke]] ''This page is about the scientific instrument maker. For other persons named Thomas Cooke, see [[Thomas Cooke (disambiguation)]]''
'''Thomas Cooke''' (8 March 1807 – 19 October 1868) was a British [[Scientific instrument|scientific instrument maker]] based in [[York]]. He founded [[T. Cooke & Sons]], the scientific [[mathematical instruments|instrument]] company.<ref name="obit_mnras">{{cite journal | last = Pritchard | first = Charles | authorlink = Charles Pritchard | title = Thomas Cooke | journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume = 29 | issue = | pages = 130–135 | publisher = [[Royal Astronomical Society]] | location = London | date = 1868 | bibcode = | url = http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/seri/MNRAS/0029//0000130.000.html | accessdate = 15 November 2015 }}</ref><ref name="argyle2007">{{cite journal | last = Argyle | first = Robert W. | author-link = | title = Thomas Cooke (1807–1868)–A Great English Telescope Maker | journal = [[The Observatory (journal)|The Observatory]] | volume = 127 | number = | pages = 392–400 | date = 2007 | bibcode = 2007Obs...127..392A | url = http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/2007Obs...127..392A | accessdate = 17 November 2015 }}</ref>
==Life== [[Image:ThomasCookeTelescope.jpg|thumb|Thomas Cooke telescope at Carter Observatory, in Wellington, New Zealand]]Thomas Cooke was born in [[Allerthorpe]], near [[Pocklington]], East Riding of Yorkshire, the son of James Cook (a [[shoemaker]]).<ref name="obit_mnras"/><ref name="genuki1">{{cite web |url = http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/YKS/ERY/Allerthorpe/Allerthorpe23.html |title = Allerthorpe Directory of Trades and Professions for 1823 |publisher = [[GENUKI]] |date = 29 May 2011 |accessdate = 10 December 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121013203639/http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/YKS/ERY/Allerthorpe/Allerthorpe23.html |archivedate = 13 October 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>Martin Lunn. "Thomas Cooke: Telescope Maker of York.” Pp.115–128 in Whitworth (2000).Whitworth, Alan. 2000. Aspects of York: Discovering Local History. Barnsley, Wharncliffe Books.</ref><ref name="odnb">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Clerke | first = A. M. | author-link = Agnes Mary Clerke | last2 = Brech | first2 = Alison J. | author2-link = | contribution = Cooke, Thomas (1807–1868) | year = 2004 | encyclopedia = [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | place = Oxford, England | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/6183 | accessdate = 7 November 2015 | chapter-url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/6183 }}</ref> His formal education consisted of two years at an elementary school (possibly the school of John Whitaker, also of Allerthorpe),<ref name="genuki1"/> but he continued learning after this and he taught himself [[navigation]] and [[astronomy]] with the intention of becoming a sailor. His mother dissuaded him from that career and he became a teacher. He made such a success of being an impromptu teacher to the farmers’ sons of the Pocklington district, that only a year later he was able to open a village school at Bielby. He continued to teach others by day and learn himself by night, and soon moved his school from Bielby to Skirpenbeck.
At Skirpenbeck he met his future wife, who was one of his pupils, and five years his junior. Fifty years on she spoke of how her husband developed his brief rudimentary education into becoming a schoolmaster: “He first learned mathematics by buying an old volume from a bookstall with a spare shilling. He also got odd sheets, and read books about geometry and mathematics, before he could buy them; for he had very little to spare”.
But Cooke’s interest in mathematics and science was practical as well academic. He had also retained his interest in navigation and instruments, and while at Skirpenbeck he made his own first rudimentary telescope – grinding a lens by hand out of the bottom of a glass whisky tumbler, then mounting in into a frame that he soldered together from a piece of tin. In 1829 he moved to [[York]] and worked as a [[Mathematics education|mathematics]] [[schoolmaster]] at the [[Archbishop Holgate's School|Rev. Schackley's School]] in Ogleforth,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=nZWESYilIYzKM6WPvaAK&num=100&id=TzwQAAAAYAAJ&dq=shackley+ogleforth+school&q=ogleforth++&pgis=1#search_anchor |title=A Brief account of Durham Cathedral: with notices of the castle, university ... – Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> near [[York Minster]]. He also taught in various [[Single-sex education|ladies' schools]] to increase his income.
His marriage to [[Hannah Cooke|Hannah]] was to produce seven children, five of whom were boys. Two of these Charles Frederick (1836–98) and Thomas (1839–1919) subsequently joined him in the business he founded in 1836 at number 50 (now renumbered to 18) [[Stonegate, York|Stonegate]], close to [[York Minster]] with the assistance of a loan of £100 from his wife's uncle.
Cooke studied [[optics]] and became interested in making [[telescope]]s, the first of which was a [[refracting telescope]] with the base of a [[Glassware|tumbler]] shaped to form its [[Lens (optics)|lens]]. This led to his friends including [[John Phillips (geologist)|John Phillips]] encouraging him to make telescopes and other optical devices commercially.<ref> {{cite book | editor-last = Feinstein | editor-first = C. H. | title = York 1831–1981:150 Years of Scientific Endeavour and Social Change | date = 1981 | publisher = The Ebor Press | isbn = 0-900657-56-1 |page=38}} </ref><ref> {{cite book | last = Willis | first = Ronald | title = The illustrated portrait of York | origyear = 1972 | edition = 4th | date = 1988 | publisher = Robert Hale Limited | isbn = 0-7090-3468-7 |page=184}} </ref><ref> {{cite book | last = McConnell | first = Anita | title = Instrument makers to the world, A history of Cooke, Troughton and Simms | origyear = 1992 | edition = 1st | date = 1992 | publisher = [[University of York]] | isbn = 1-85072-096-7 |page=50}} </ref>
==Work== In 1837 he established his first optical business in a small shop at 50 Stonegate, York, and later moved to larger premises in Coney Street. He built his first telescope for William Gray. At that time, the excise tax on glass discouraged the making of [[refracting telescope]]s, which were usually imported from abroad. Cooke was thus one of the pioneers of making such telescopes in Britain.
He made more instruments and built his reputation. He was not only an optician but had mechanical abilities as well, and among other things, manufactured turret clocks for church towers. He founded the firm [[T. Cooke & Sons]]. In 1855 he moved to bigger premises, the Buckingham Works at [[Bishophill]] in York, where factory methods of production were first applied to optical instruments.<ref> {{cite book | editor-last = Feinsten | editor-first = C. H. | title = York 1831–1981:150 Years of Scientific Endeavour and Social Change | date = 1981 | publisher = The Ebor Press | isbn = 0-900657-56-1 |page=39}} </ref> He exhibited at the York Exhibition in 1866 demonstrating his three-wheeled, steam powered car which he claimed could carry 15 people at 15 mph for a distance of 40 miles.<ref name='PockHistory'>{{cite web |url=http://www.pocklingtonhistory.com/archives/people/famous/thomascooke/ |title=Thomas Cooke |last= Gilbank|first= P. |accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref>
One of his finest achievements was the construction of the 25-inch 'Newall' refractor for [[Robert Stirling Newall]]; sadly, Thomas died before seeing it completed. For some years the Newall was the largest refracting telescope in the world.<ref name='Newall1'>{{cite web |url=http://www.hasi.gr/instruments/ast73 |title=Newall Refractor |author=The Hellenic Archives of Scientific Instruments |accessdate= 16 March 2014}}</ref> On Newall's death it was donated to the [[Cambridge Observatory]] and finally moved in 1959 to Mount Penteli observatory in [[Penteli, Greece]]. He made a telescope for the Royal Observatory, also Greenwich and another for Prince Albert. The firm amalgamated with Troughton & Simms (London) to become Cooke, Troughton & Simms in 1922 and this later became part of [[Vickers]], but still run by his sons Thomas & Frederick.
Thomas Cooke was succeeded by his sons, Thomas and Frederick. He is buried in [[York Cemetery, York|York Cemetery]].
==Telescopes in use today== [[Image:CarterObs5.jpg|thumb|Thomas Cooke telescope at Carter Observatory, in Wellington, New Zealand]] [[Image:Bootham School Observatory (2007).jpg|thumb|upright|Thomas Cooke refractor in Bootham School Observatory]]
*A telescope made by Thomas Cooke is still in daily use at [[Carter Observatory]] – The National Observatory of New Zealand, delivering excellent results. The original 9-inch triplet lens has been replaced by a 9 1/2 doublet made by renowned optician Garry Nankivell. *At the observatory in [[York Museum Gardens#19th and 20th century|the Museum Gardens]], [[York]] there is a working 4-inch telescope, built for the [[Yorkshire Philosophical Society]] in 1850. A second unit of the same construction was purchased and installed in the observatory at [[Bootham School]], York in 1854. A third matching instrument, dating from the same period, was donated to [[The Friends' School, Hobart|Friendsʼ School, Hobart]] in 1974 by the grandson of [[Michael Pease|Jonathan Backhouse Hodgkin]]. All three instruments remain in active service. *A 5" refractor dating from 1883 is still in use at [[Coats Observatory, Paisley]], Scotland . *A 5" refractor dating from 1880 is still in regular use at Clanfield Observatory, Hampshire.<ref>{{cite web|first=Matt |last=Charman |url=http://www.hantsastro.org.uk/tour/5inch.php |title=5-inch and 4.5-inch Telescopes – Hampshire Astronomical Group (HAG) – Clanfield Observatory |location=Hampshire Astronomical Group, Clanfield Observatory, Hampshire, UK |publisher=Hantsastro.org.uk |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> *There is a 6" Cooke telescope in the [[Airdrie Public Observatory]], Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, Scotland run by the [[Airdrie Astronomical Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.airdrieobservatory.com |title=AAA Home Page |publisher=Airdrieobservatory.com |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> * A 6” Cooke refractor is the main telescope in use at the [[Hampstead Scientific Society#Hampstead Observatory|Hampstead Observatory]] in [[London]]. Known as the ’Wildey telescope’ (in tribute to renowned master optician, [[Henry Wildey]]), the telescope can be used by the public on the observatory’s open nights (most Friday and Saturdays).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hampsteadscience.ac.uk/astro/observatory.html |title=HSS Hampstead Observatory|publisher= hampsteadscience.ac.uk |accessdate=9 January 2017}}</ref> * There is a 6" Cooke telescope in use at the Baxendell Observatory in [[Hesketh Park, Southport]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fernleyobservatory.org |title=Home Page |publisher=fernleyobservatory.org |accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref> * A 6" Cooke refractor exists in the 1929 observatory of the University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsandscience.usask.ca/physics/observatory/ |title=University of Saskatchewan Observatory |publisher=artsandscience.usask.ca |accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> * A 6.25" refractor known as the 'Lockyer Telescope' is in use at the [[Norman Lockyer Observatory]] in [[Sidmouth]], [[Devon]], [[UK]]. The lens, made by Cooke, was first used in 1865 in a telescope built by [[Norman Lockyer]]. Cooke later rebuilt the telescope in its present form in 1871. The telescope was positioned in several locations before being moved to Sidmouth in 1912, where it remains. Lockyer used this telescope to discover [[helium]] in the sun's [[corona]]. It was restored in 1995 and is now used mainly for public-outreach.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://projects.exeter.ac.uk/nlo/tour/lockyertelescope.htm |title= The Lockyer 6¼-inch refractor (circa 1871) |accessdate= 9 September 2017}}</ref> *A 6.5" refractor manufactured in 1870 is in use at the Assheton Observatory at [[Rossall School]]. *A 6.5" refractor manufactured in 1876 is in use at the Astronomic Observatory<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astro-observ.odessa.ua/ |title=AO | Одесская астрономическая обсерватория |publisher=Astro-observ.odessa.ua |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> of the [[Odessa University|Odessa National University]] in [[Odessa]], Ukraine. *An 8" refractor dating from 1864, known as the Thorrowgood Telescope belongs to the [[Royal Astronomical Society]] and is operated at the [[Cambridge Observatory]]. *An 8" refractor is housed in the Jeremiah Horrocks Observatory, [[Moor Park, Preston]], Lancashire. *The Fry telescope,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulo.ucl.ac.uk/telescopes/fry/ |title=Fry Telescope |publisher=Ulo.ucl.ac.uk |date=17 April 2012 |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> an 8" refractor manufactured in 1862, is in regular use at the University of London Observatory<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulo.ucl.ac.uk |title=ULO Home Page |publisher=Ulo.ucl.ac.uk |date=17 April 2012 |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> in Mill Hill, London. *A 10" refractor from 1860 is in use at the Blackett Observatory, Wiltshire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackettobservatory.org/about.html |title=About |publisher=Blackett Observatory |date=11 October 2002 |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> *A 10" refractor from 1871, which was purchased by [[University of St Andrews|St. Andrews]] in 1938 and used as a training telescope, has been in use since 1951 at [[Mills Observatory]], Dundee, Scotland. *A 25" refractor from 1869 "Newall Telescope" is in use at the [[National Observatory of Athens]], Penteli, Greece<ref name='Newall1' />

[[File:William James b1842c.jpg|thumb|right|190px| [[William James]] (1842-1910) c.1890. With his essay ''The Moral Equivalent of War'' he is considered <ref>Aberkane 2010</ref> one of the fathers of the concept of '''war against war''']] In [[political philosophy]] and [[international relations]] especially in [[peace and conflict studies]] the concept of a '''war against war''' also known as '''war on war''' refers to the [[Concretization|reification]] of [[armed conflicts]].
==Origin== [[File:Berlin plaque Ernst Friedrich.jpg|thumb|left|190px| Memorial plaque for [[Ernst Friedrich]] at the 'Antikriegsmuseum' (anti-war museum) in [[Berlin-Mitte]], Germany. One can read the title of Friedrich's book 'Krieg dem kriege"]] If a work of [[Edmond Potonié-Pierre]] from 1877 already discusses the idea of reifying conflicts under the title "''la guerre à la guerre''" (''the war against war'')<ref>Edmond Pontonié-Pierre ''La Guerre à la Guerre'' 1877</ref> in its modern acceptation the concept is formally coined in 1906 by [[William James]] in his essay [[s:The Moral Equivalent of War|''The moral equivalent of war'']]. Though also used as a political slogan, it was a cornerstone of the ideology of both the European pre World War I [[Pacifism#World War I|pacifist]] and [[Anti-war movement#World War I|anti-war]] movements in the 20th century<ref>Francis Ludwig Carsten War against war: British and German radical movements in the First World War, University of California Press 1982</ref> especially in its German version of ''Kriege dem Kriege'' from the eponymous two volume 1925 pamphlet of Ernst Friedrich<ref>Ernst Friederich, Kriege dem Kriege! 2 vol "Freie Jugend", 1925</ref> which was largely translated across Europe. Prior to World War I the French labour union ''[[Confédération Générale du Travail]]'' pleaded its pacifism under the slogan ''guerre à la guerre!'' which was also the title of a poster campaign by which the French ''[[Association de la Paix par le Droit]]'' recalled the commitments taken by European powers at the [[Hague Convention of 1907]].<ref>"''Guerre à la Guerre!''" ''campagne d'affichage de l'Association pour la Paix par le Droit'' [https://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/15801/DBEE72DCADF6B6D8C648CEDA446023D22AC4CED6.html exemplaire d'une affiche disponible à la Bibliothèque Municipale de Lyon, France]</ref>
==Evolution in the 20th century== Although the slogan and concept (as the reification of armed conflicts) of ''war against war'' was the subject of an anti-military pleading in 1916 at the [[military tribunal]] of [[Neuchâtel]]<ref>Jules Humbert-Droz ''Guerre à la guerre: à bas l'armée : plaidoirie complète devant le Tribunal militaire à Neuchâtel le 16 août 1916''</ref> the concept will also be developed by the [[French military]] with General [[Alexandre Percin]], then War Minister, dedicating a comprehensive study to the subject entitled ''Guerre à la Guerre''.<ref>Alexandre Percin, ''Guerre à la Guerre'' Paris: Montaigne 1927</ref> The latter work, which especially explores the [[Military operation|operational]] and [[Military strategy|strategic]] dimension of the concept from the angle of [[military doctrine]] would become a seminal contribution to its academic establishment. At times defended by the [[Socialist International]] as in the 1923 discourse of labour unionist [[Edo Fimmen]] at the international congress for peace at the Hague<ref>Edo Fimmen, discours prononcé par Edo Fimmen au Congrès international pour la paix La Haye, du 10 au 15 décembre 1922''Guerre à la guerre: la tâche du prolétariat organisé dans le mouvement pour la paix mondiale''</ref> the concept will remain politically neutral overall in the 20th century, being also claimed by the [[Christian democracy|Christian democratic movement]] with Gérard Marier and Jean Godin considering [[nuclear disarmament]] a central contribution to the war on war as a [[Christian]] mission<ref>Gérard Marier, Jean Godin, ''Guerre à la guerre: le catholique devant la folie nucléaire'' Paris 1963</ref>
==Contemporary evolution== [[File:Jean-Jacques Lebel (2008).png|thumb|right|200px|Jean-Jacques Lebel in 2008, in 1982 the poet took part in the collective work of UNESCO "''War on war; poets of the world at Unesco''" along with Allen Ginsberg.]] [[File:Allen ginsberg 675.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Allen Ginsberg, 1979]]
===Unesco=== The [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] which constitution<ref>[http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=15244&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html constitution de l'UNESCO, signée le 16 novembre 1945, en vigueur le 4 novembre 1946]</ref> declares "''That since wars begin in the minds of men, it is in the minds of men that the defences of peace must be constructed''" describing a [[Memetics|memetical]] conception of war, brought together - in 1982 - thirteen poets for a collective work entitled "''War on war : The poet's cry''". <ref> Lebel, Jean Jacques; Adonis; Ai Qing; Breytenbach, Breyten; Cardenal, Ernesto; Cortez, Jayne; Faye, Jean Pierre; Ginsberg, Allen; Tan'si, Sony Labou; Mello, Thiago de; Pritam, Amrita; Shiraishi, Kazuko; Voznesenski, Andrei '' War on war; poets of the world at Unesco''</ref>
===Aberkane & Goldstein and a peace [[positivism]]=== More recently the concept was discussed by scholars [[Joshua Goldstein]]<ref>Joshua Goldstein ''Winning the War on War: The Decline of Armed Conflict'' Worldwide Foreign Affairs, November/December 2011</ref> and [[Idriss Aberkane]].<ref>Idriss Aberkane ''On the "war on war" in modern geopolitics'' e-international relations January 9th 2012</ref> As Aberkane defines it "''it permits us to ask, before the war disease reaches its terminal phase, "has man domesticated war, or has war domesticated man?"''". Based on the paradigm of [[Humberto Maturana]] and [[Francisco Varela]] for the description of autonomy and the works of [[Idries Shah]] in [[group psychology]] Aberkane's discussion of the concept consists of considering armed conflicts [[Autopoiesis|autopoietic]] and therefore [[dissipative system]]s which are [[Parasitism|parasitic]] and comparable to [[Richard Dawkins]]' notion of [[selfish gene theory|selfish gene]] hence "''selfish wars''".<ref>Aberkane 2012, ibid</ref> Conceptually Aberkane argues for a prescriptive use of peace and conflict studies, especially in a study on the defusing of the [[History of Xinjiang#Continued tensions|tensions in Xinjiang]]<ref>Aberkane, Idriss "''Yin or Yang: China and the Muslim World''" e-International Relations, 29 avril 2011, §4</ref> by which he defends the logical soundness of the concept of a "war against war" in five points: * (i) "''the qualitative complexity of the notion of [[National interest|interest]] (e.g. What you may think is not your interest may be in a broader perspective)''" * (ii) "''the non-refuted possibility that external [[Conflict of interest|conflicts of interests]] may be internalized within one single interest,''" * (iii)"'' the fact that [[Hilbert's sixth problem]] has not been solved (ie physical reality is not axiomatized) which implies that''" * (iv) "''while [[Gödel's incompleteness theorems|limitation theorems]] can be demonstrated in [[first order logic]] (and [[game theory]]) there can be no limitation theorem predicating upon physical reality which comprises the notion of interest, thus in particular''" * (v) "''the impossibility of the total interest of peace ie. the stable intersection of individual and collective peace in international relations cannot be demonstrated.''" What Aberkane thus describes as "''erenologic positivism''" is transcribed in game theoretical vocabulary as that in international relations "''it is also not proven that a [[Pareto optimality|Pareto-optimal]] situation at the world level (or at a less formal level of describing diplomatic reality, a situation that may be reminiscent to the latter without its mathematical precision) could not be also overlapping with the [[Nash equilibrium]] of interacting individual interests.''"<ref>Aberkane, Ibid 2011</ref>
===Peace–industrial complex=== {{Further information|Peace–industrial complex}} At least two approaches to the '''war against war''' may be distinguished, the frontal opposition to war or [[Anti-war movement]] on the one side and the transcendent, post-war conception of [[William James]]' 'Moral Equivalent of war' positing, in the way of the [[UNESCO]], that the only way to end conflicts is to make Humanity busy with more fascinating endeavors than wars. In his Nobel acceptance speech [[Martin Luther King]] further underlined that idea which would become the basis of the transcendentist school (e.g. Aberkane):
{{cquote| We will not build a peaceful world by following a negative path. It is not enough to say "We must not wage war." It is necessary to love peace and sacrifice for it. We must concentrate not merely on the negative expulsion of war, but on the positive affirmation of peace. There is a fascinating little story that is preserved for us in Greek literature about [[Odysseus|Ulysses]] and the [[Siren (mythology)|Sirens]]. The Sirens had the ability to sing so sweetly that sailors could not resist steering toward their island. Many ships were lured upon the rocks, and men forgot home, duty, and honor as they flung themselves into the sea to be embraced by arms that drew them down to death. Ulysses, determined not to be lured by the Sirens, first decided to tie himself tightly to the mast of his boat, and his crew stuffed their ears with wax. But finally he and his crew learned a better way to save themselves: they took on board the beautiful singer [[Orpheus]] whose melodies were sweeter than the music of the Sirens. When Orpheus sang, who bothered to listen to the Sirens? <ref>[https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/1964/king-lecture.html Martin Luther King, Nobel Lecture, Dec. 11th 1964]</ref> }}
[[File:Martin Luther King, Jr..jpg|thumb|right|200px| Official picture of Martin Luther King Jr. at the Nobel Foundation, 1964]]
Various scholars (Suter 1986, Aberkane 2012, Roberts 2009) and politicians (Seiberling 1972) have thus advocated that peace profiteering should simply be made palatably larger than any possible [[war profiteering]], thus transcending the war against war. However, the first generations of Peace-Industrial scholars have advocated frontal opposition to the [[military–industrial complex]] rather than its transcendent, voluntary metamorphosis into a globally benevolent yet very profitable peace-industrial complex.
[[File:John F. Seiberling 93rd Congress 1973.jpg|thumb|right|200px| US. Rep. John F. Seiberling circa the time of his 1972 address to the Congress calling for a Peace-industrial complex]]
In 1986 [[Keith Suter|Keith D. Suter]] defended his Ph.D dissertation on ''Creating the political will necessary for achieving multilateral disarmament : the need for a peace-industrial complex'',<ref>Suter, K. D. Creating the political will necessary for achieving multilateral disarmament : the need for a peace-industrial complex, Ph.D Thesis, Deakin University, Victoria, 1986 [https://books.google.com/books?id=kwAcNQAACAAJ&dq=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZNSIUYLxH8aM0AWzzIHICw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ]</ref> which was further cited in 1995.<ref>Summy, R. Salla, M.E 'Why the Cold War Ended: A Range of Interpretations' Greenwood Publishing Group, 1995 p.202</ref> The concept of a Peace-industrial complex had already been introduced as early as in 1969 in the U.S. Senate Committee on Government Operations.<ref>United States. Congress. Senate. Committee on Government Operations, U.S. Government Printing Office, 1969 p.147 [https://books.google.com/books?id=RJ83AAAAIAAJ&q=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&dq=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZNSIUYLxH8aM0AWzzIHICw&ved=0CFkQ6AEwCQ]</ref> The original quote affirmed direct opposition to the military-industrial complex and was therefore not transcendent in nature: "It is time for the United States to break the Huge military-industrial complex and begin in its stead a people and peace-industrial complex". It received further citation throughout the 1970s. The notion appeared in the [[United States Congress House Committee on Science and Astronautics]], Subcommittee on Science, Research, and Development in 1972 <ref>National science policy and priorities act of 1972: Hearings, Ninety-second Congress, second session U.S. Govt. Print. Off., 1972 p.153 [https://books.google.com/books?id=kXsqAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&dq=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zdeIUc3mB-210QWkg4CIBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgK]</ref> in a congressional address by US [[John F. Seiberling|Rep. J. F. Seiberling]] (1972) <ref>Rep. J. F. Seiberling, "The case for economic conversion" Congressional record v.118, n°95, 13 June 1972, pp E6177-6179, cited in Science Policy Reviews, Volumes 4 à 5 Battelle Memorial Institute, 1972 p. 398 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ggQFAAAAIAAJ&q=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&dq=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zdeIUc3mB-210QWkg4CIBw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAjgK], see also Congressional Record: Proceedings and Debates of the US Congress, Volume 118, Part 16 U.S. Government Printing Office, 1972 p.20738 [https://books.google.com/books?id=G20Udh7ynykC&q=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&dq=%22Peace-Industrial+Complex%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zdeIUc3mB-210QWkg4CIBw&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBjgK]</ref>
Suter further defended that "each country create a national Ministry for Peace",<ref>[http://www.i4pinternational.org/files/202/7.+national+ministries+for+peace.pdf]</ref> which was contemporary to the creation of the Ministry for Peace Australia (MFPA) initiative and the Global Alliance for Ministries & Infrastructures for Peace (GAMIP). An Education for a Peace Industrial Complex conference (EPIC) is also mentioned in a 1984 issue of the Nuclear Times.<ref>Nuclear Times, Volumes 3 to 4, 1984</ref>
If Kofi J. Roberts <ref>Roberts K. J. The Sargasso Bridge, iUniverse 2009 p. 185</ref> explicitly called for the substitution of a military-industrial complex by a peace industrial complex which would enable the focusing on federal spendings on construction rather than destruction, Idriss J. Aberkane further defended the transcendent approach to the peace-industrial complex by calling it the "military-industrial complex 2.0" and thus neither the enemy nor the political complement to the military industrial complex but rather its natural, inevitable evolution on the account that investors (either institutional or private) will inevitably realize the larger profitability of construction over destruction. Aberkane also advocates the political viability of a peace-industrial complex by declaring that in the 21st century, what he calls "weapons of mass construction" will grant much larger political leverage, leadership and [[soft power]] than weapons of mass destruction.
{{cquote| every time a military technology makes it to civilian use it changes the world for good and what it brings you is love rather than hatred, for if you project destruction you're gonna be hated, if you project construction, you're gonna be loved. So what is power, truly, what is a [[superpower]]? Is it a nation that has [[Weapon of mass destruction|weapons of mass destruction]]? No it is not! Many nations have weapons of mass destruction they are not all superpowers (...) when you're looking at [[The Pentagon]] you're looking at a [[Military budget of the United States|budget]] of 740 billion US dollars, that's the budget of the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] plus de [[Expenditures in the United States federal budget#Discretionary spending|discretionary budget]] that is allocated to Research and Development for defense. I'm not saying we should take it away from the Pentagon, I say we should move to the Pentagon 2.0. For so far, what has America gained in projecting every bits of these dollars? Every time America uses these dollars is it more loved? Is it more respected? Is it safer? Is it more trusted? Does it have more leadership? (...) America could project this money to gain love, respect, leadership and political power. This, is the military-industrial complex 2.0. [It] will be interested in weapons of mass construction rather than weapons of mass destruction because these weapons are the future in terms of power. For what was the power of the 20th century? In the 20th century power was [[Nuclear winter|the ability to go from a beautiful blue planet to a red one]]. If you could turn a blue planet into a red one you were powerful. We have the technology to do that, these (sic) are called weapons of mass construction. Do we have the technology to go the other way around? Can we [[Terraforming|turn a red planet - Mars in that case - into a beautiful green planet]]? We can't but when you're looking at a budget of seven hundred billions US dollars you can look into that. This is gonna be 21st century power, weapons of mass construction. Why? because if you project these weapons I guarantee you people are gonna love you }} <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XLIzupsfiV8 Aberkane, Bring on the Peace-Industrial Complex, Wikistage Paris 2013]</ref>
